key_title: Key to the species of Craspedia

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Asteraceae

source.author: Scmidt-Lebuhn, A.N.; Milner, K.V.
source.title: A quantitative study of morphology in Australian Craspedia (Asteraceae, Gnaphalieae)
source.citation: From: Scmidt-Lebuhn, A.N.; Milner, K.V. (2013). A quantitative study of morphology in Australian Craspedia (Asteraceae, Gnaphalieae). Australian Systematic Botany 26:238-254.

leads.lead_text: Short-lived plant with a single tap-root; north-west
Perennial plant with many secondary roots
Flowers white
Flowers yellow or orange
At least the abaxial leaf surfaces with numerous woolly hairs

Leaf surfaces glabrous or with septate or glandular hairs but without woolly hairs (rarely few hairs with a robust septate base and a thin apex especially on central vein, or woolly hairs forming a fringe restricted to leaf margins)
Leaves discolorous with abaxial surfaces more densely hairy than the adaxial ones, sticky-glandular, often aromatic when crushed with a scent reminiscent of orange peel
Leaves usually concolorous, not sticky
Robust plants with very densely white-woolly leaves (at least on the abaxial surfaces); inflorescences (25–)30–40 mm in diameter; alpine
Small to robust plants with sparsely to densely silvery grey-woolly leaf surfaces; inflorescences 12–30 mm in diameter
Rosette leaves sparsely to densely hairy, with two somewhat indistinct arching secondary veins; lowland
Rosette leaves moderately to densely hairy, with two or four very distinct secondary veins running parallel to the central vein; subalpine
Plants mostly above 50 cm high and up to 1 m; rosette leaves narrowly oblanceolate to oblong, often greater than 15 cm long, usually glabrous or glabrescent; mostly lowland swamps and drainage lines

Plants mostly 50 cm high or lower; rosette leaves obovate to oblanceolate (or narrower in rare C. basaltica of western basalt plains), mostly conspicuously hairy, or if glabrous on the lamina, an alpine species
Rosette leaves with leaf bases broadly attenuate and (2–)3–10(–20) mm wide at base; subalpine to alpine
Rosette leaves with leaf bases long-attenuate and 1.5–4(–6) mm wide at base; lowland to subalpine
Rosette leaves subglabrous except for a fringe of hairs around the margins; moist to wet habitats
Surfaces of rosette leaves with robust septate hairs; drier habitats
Flowers always yellow; lowland
Flowers usually orange, more rarely yellow; montane or subalpine
Leaves 10 mm wide or less, blade less than half the total leaf length, base conspicuously red-tinged
Widest leaves usually more than 12 (rarely c. 8) mm wide, blade more than half the total leaf length, base green or white
Basal leaves linear-spathulate to spathulate, the widest to 12 mm wide, mostly long-attenuate at base; moist grassland in subalpine areas
Basal leaves broadly spathulate, the widest 20–40 mm wide, very long-attenuate at base; grassy understorey of montane woodland
